com.tranek.chivalryserverbrowser

Class GamepadKeybindDialog

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window
          • java.awt.Dialog
            • javax.swing.JDialog
              • com.tranek.chivalryserverbrowser.GamepadKeybindDialog
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class GamepadKeybindDialog
extends javax.swing.JDialog
    The dialog that pops up for editing the gamepad button binds. It presents the user with a table of the current commands bound to a button with the option of changing the order of the commands, editing the commands, adding a new command, and removing a command.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • addCommand

        public void addCommand()
        Adds a new command to the JTable of commands. It creates a new JComboBox, adds it to the table, and then opens the drop down list automatically for the user with the description of all of the commands.
        See Also:
        Keybinds.commandDescriptions

      • removeCommand

        public void removeCommand()
        Removes the selected command from the JTable.

      • moveCommandUp

        public void moveCommandUp()
        Moves the selected command up in the JTable assuming that it is not the first row. The JComboBox for this row can sometimes get messed up if the user selects a row (causing the drop down menu to open) and clicks outside of the JTable to close the drop down. It can be seen by the text being partially hidden. The workaround for this is to get a reference to the JComboBox and then set its selected index to its current index.
        See Also:
        JTable.getCellEditor(int, int), TableCellEditor.getTableCellEditorComponent(JTable, Object, boolean, int, int), JComboBox.setSelectedIndex(int), JComboBox.getSelectedIndex()

      • moveCommandDown

        public void moveCommandDown()
        Moves the selected command down in the JTable assuming that it is not the last row. The JComboBox for this row can sometimes get messed up if the user selects a row (causing the drop down menu to open) and clicks outside of the JTable to close the drop down. It can be seen by the text being partially hidden. The workaround for this is to get a reference to the JComboBox and then set its selected index to its current index.
        See Also:
        JTable.getCellEditor(int, int), TableCellEditor.getTableCellEditorComponent(JTable, Object, boolean, int, int), JComboBox.setSelectedIndex(int), JComboBox.getSelectedIndex()

      • showDialog

        public void showDialog()
        Sets this dialog's visibility to true.
        See Also:
        Dialog.setVisible(boolean)

      • getBindingAndAddToTable

        public void getBindingAndAddToTable(java.lang.String file,
                           java.lang.String button)
        Gets the commands bound to a particular gamepad button and adds them to the JTable. It looks for the configuration file in the user's "Documents\My Games\Chivalry Medieval Warefare\UDKGame\Config" directory.
        Parameters:
        file - the configuration file where the bindings are located
        button - the gamepad button to get the bindings for
        See Also:
        Keybinds, JFileChooser.getFileSystemView(), FileSystemView.getDefaultDirectory(), BufferedReader, FileReader

      • getCommands

        public java.lang.String getCommands(java.lang.String file,
                           java.lang.String button)
        Gets the commands bound to a particular gamepad button. It looks for the configuration file in the user's "Documents\My Games\Chivalry Medieval Warefare\UDKGame\Config" directory.
        Parameters:
        file - the configuration file where the bindings are located
        button - the gamepad button to get the bindings for
        Returns:
        the commands separated by " | "
        See Also:
        Keybinds, JFileChooser.getFileSystemView(), FileSystemView.getDefaultDirectory(), BufferedReader, FileReader

      • writeBinding

        public boolean writeBinding(java.lang.String file,
                   java.lang.String button,
                   java.lang.String commands)
        Writes a new binding for a button to the configuration file.
        Parameters:
        file - the configuration file where the bindings are located
        button - the gamepad button to write the bindings for
        commands - the commands to write for the gamepad button
        Returns:
        true if successfully written to the config file; false otherwise
        See Also:
        Keybinds, JFileChooser.getFileSystemView(), FileSystemView.getDefaultDirectory(), BufferedReader, FileReader, FileWriter, BufferedWriter
